Input.threadtitle: Proof that $$\sqrt3$$ is irrational [POSSIBLE SPOILER]
Input.posts:
Okay so here's my attempt at proving $$\sqrt3$$ is irrational. Feedback, as always, would be most appreciated. Theorem: $$\sqrt3$$ is irrational Proof: Assuming the contrary, $$\sqrt3$$ is rational, then there are no common factors for natural numbers $$p, q$$ such that $$\sqrt3 = p / q$$. Squaring gives $$3 = p^2 / q^2$$. Rearranging gives $$3q^2 = p^2$$. So $$p^2$$ must be divisible by 3 thus $$p^2 = 3r$$ for some $$r$$. Substituting gives $$3q^2 = (3r)^2 = 9r^2$$. Simplifying gives $$q^2 = 3r^2$$. Both $$p$$ and $$q$$ divide 3 so 3 is a factor of both $$p$$ and $$q$$. But this is impossible since $$p$$ and $$q$$ have no common factors. As a result, the original assumption of $$\sqrt3$$ is rational is false. hence $$\sqrt3$$ must be irrational.

Based on what I learnt in PS3, ∀x[P(x)] should in fact read as: 'all numbers are prime'. The difference in meaning between these two statements, I cannot understand: 1. ∀x∃y[Prime(x) ∧ Prime(y) ∧(x < y)] - All natural numbers are prime 2. ∀x[P(x) ⇒ O(x)] - All primes have property y... Is it because one is a component of a conditional statement, and one is a component of a conjunct? Even if this is the case I don't understand why the implications are so different, ie 1. All natural numbers are prime, and 2. All primes have property y... help...?

Natalya, There is an important observation you must bring to both statements you list above. That is, that there is not last prime number as was demonstrated by Euler's proof! Knowing this we can read $$\forall x\exists y[Prime(x) \wedge Prime(y) \wedge (y > x)]$$ for every x in the set of Prime Numbers that we choose, there is at least one other Prime number after it. In this statement x and y are both natural numbers so P(y) comes after P(x). When we are discussing a finite set, like the number of people on the earth, he $$\forall x$$ is nterpreted as 'for every member in the set', however, when the set is unbounded the interpretation is more like every member we can select. The statement $$\forall x [P(x) \Rightarrow O(x)]$$ is different in that it takes advantage of a common property of the set of prime numbers. That is, a prime number is not divisible by another prime number smaller than itself (assuming 1 is not a prime number). So we know the infinite set of prime numbers greater than 2 share the common property which is that none of them are divisible by 2 which is a prime number. I hope this helps
